1. Data blocks

data-blocks.Rmd

Introduction

Data blocks are the starting point of any stack and are required by any transform or plot block.

Package based data block

{blockr} introduces a data_block() which takes as input any package containing a (or multiple) dataset(s). This block is constructed as follows:

new_data_block <- function(
  ...,
  dat = as.environment("package:datasets"),
  selected = character()
) {
  # code  
}

By default, the selected dataset is from the datasets package but you can actually provide any dataset you like by changing the dat parameter (in the following we leverage the {blockr.data} datasets with the lab data pre-selected):

# Define the custom data block
custom_data_block <- function(...) {
  data_block(
    dat = as.environment("package:blockr.data"),
    selected = "lab",
    ...
  )
}

stack <- new_stack(
  custom_data_block, 
  select_block
)
serve_stack(stack)
In the registry vignette, we see how to register a block in a cleaner way.

In practice, you’ll always call data_block() and not new_data_block() (internal constructor).

Overall, this block is good for testing or if you get your own data package. In the next part, we see how to import data from a file.

Reading data from files

{blockr} exposes 2 extra data blocks which have to be combined with one of the 5 following data parser blocks:

  • xpt_block, reads xpt files.
  • sas_block, reads sas7bdat files.
  • rds_block, reads rds files.
  • json_block, reads json files.
  • csv_block, reads csv files.

Upload data

If you want to load data from any location on your computer, upload_block() is what you need. Since the upload_block() temporarily moves the data in a custom location, we recognize that it might not be always possible for security reasons.

library(blockr)

stack <- new_stack(
  upload_block,
  csv_block,
  select_block
)
serve_stack(stack)

Files browser block

filesbrowser_block() can read data from the server file system. It means that if no data is available on the server, you won’t see anything. You can customize the accessible locations as follows, through the volumes parameter:

custom_filesbrowser_block <- function(...) {
  filesbrowser_block(
    volumes = c(vol1 = "<PATH1>", vol2 = "<PATH2>"),
    ...
  )
}

In the following demonstration, we uploaded a dummy dataset on the webR file system so you can play with the block. That said, you can definitely upload your own data thanks to the corresponding shinylive feature (upload button).

library(blockr)

stack <- new_stack(
  filesbrowser_block,
  csv_block,
  select_block
)
serve_stack(stack)

Note that in a later release, we plan to merge filesbrowser_block() and upload_block() into a single variable block.

Reading data from another stack

result_block() allows to read data from another stack. From the below code, the first stack contains a data_block() from which the n-th first rows are pulled by the head_block(). In the second stack, we can reuse this smaller dataset. If you dynamically add a third stack, you can also select the third stack output as input of the second stack (it appears in the result block select input).

library(blockr)

serve_workspace(
  stack1 = new_stack(data_block, head_block),
  stack2 = new_stack(result_block),
  title = "My workspace"
)
